description:
Lupin III chronicles the adventures of Arsene Lupin III, the world's greatest thief, and his partners in crime: master marksman Daisuke Jigen, beautiful and scheming Fujiko Mine and stoic samurai Goemon Ishikawa XIII. Lupin and his gang travel around the globe in search of the world's greatest treasures and riches and always keeping one step ahead of the tireless Inspector Zenigata, who has vowed to bring Lupin to justice.

(Source: AnimeNewsNetwork)

tags.name: Anti-Hero
tags.description: Features a protagonist who lacks conventional heroic attributes and may be considered a borderline villain.

tags.name: Fugitive
tags.description: Prominently features a character evading capture by an individual or organization.

tags.name: Episodic
tags.description: Features story arcs that are loosely tied or lack an overarching plot.

tags.name: Primarily Adult Cast
tags.description: Main cast is mostly composed of characters above a high school age.

tags.name: Crime
tags.description: Centers around unlawful activities punishable by the state or other authority.

tags.name: Detective
tags.description: Features a character who investigates and solves crimes.

tags.name: Police
tags.description: Centers around the life and activities of law enforcement officers.

tags.name: Travel
tags.description: Centers around character(s) moving between places a significant distance apart.

tags.name: Samurai
tags.description: Prominently features warriors of medieval Japanese nobility bound by a code of honor.

tags.name: Nudity
tags.description: Features a character wearing no clothing or exposing intimate body parts.

node.description:
Monkey Punch is the pen name of mangaka Kazuhiko Katou, creator of the successful Japanese manga series [Lupin III](https://anilist.co/manga/30438/), which is still being animated to this day.

Influenced by [Osamu Tezuka](https://anilist.co/staff/96938/)'s works, he began to draw and moved to Tokyo in 1957 after graduating from high school. From 1959, he wrote for a publishing company specializing in rental books under the pen name "Kazuhiko Katou," while working on doujins with his younger brother, Teruhiko Katou, and another friend. After moving to Tokyo, he was influenced by the American parody magazine "MAD," and his style changed to an American comic book style. This caught the attention of Fumito Shimizu, editor-in-chief of Futabasha, and in 1966 he made his full-fledged debut with Playboy Nyuumon under the pen name Eiji Muta. Under the name of "Mania Group," it was made to look as if Senji Mashuu (摩周仙二) and Eiji Kirita (霧多永二) were participating, but in reality, Katou wrote the whole story by himself.

In 1966, under the orders of editor-in-chief Shimizu, he changed his pen name to Monkey Punch. Katou didn't like the name because it was given to a newcomer at random, and he planned to change it after about a year, but he couldn't change it because the work he published under this name the following year became a big hit.

In May 1967, he was selected to draw the cover art for "Zengan Manga Story Action Tokushuu-gou," which was published mainly for newcomers to "Manga Story," such as Baron Yoshimoto and Ken Tsukikage, and he continued to draw the cover art for "Shuukan Manga Action," a weekly seinen manga magazine that was newly launched in August with Shimizu as editor-in-chief. He also began serializing Lupin III under the title with the notation "Original by [Leblanc](https://anilist.co/staff/122907/)." in the August 10 first issue of Manga Action.

In addition to Lupin III, he has also created works such as Fukushuu Daikou, [Cinderella Boy](https://anilist.co/manga/71117/), and [MUSASHI: Gundou](https://anilist.co/anime/1200/). In 1996, he took on the challenge of directing an animated film with [Lupin III: Dead or Alive](https://anilist.co/anime/1416/).

He passed away due to pneumonia on April 11, 2019.

**Awards:**
- Inkpot Award
- Rome Comic Festival ROMICS Gold Award
- AMD Award for Merit
- Japan Cartoonists Association Award Minister of Education, Culture, Sports, Science and Technology Award

(Source: Wikipedia)

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/%E3%81%93%E3%81%A0%E3%81%BE%E5%85%BC%E5%97%A3) | [Wiki (en)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kenji_Kodama)

Kenji Kodama is a Japanese director and storyboard artist. He is best known for being one of the main directors on the long-running anime [Detective Conan](https://anilist.co/anime/235/), as well as the [City Hunter](https://anilist.co/anime/1470/) series and [Lupin III: Part III](https://anilist.co/anime/1426/).

Married to animator [Sachiko Kamimura](https://anilist.co/staff/112663/).

(Source: Wikipedia)

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/%E3%81%93%E3%81%A0%E3%81%BE%E5%85%BC%E5%97%A3) | [Wiki (en)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kenji_Kodama)

Kenji Kodama is a Japanese director and storyboard artist. He is best known for being one of the main directors on the long-running anime [Detective Conan](https://anilist.co/anime/235/), as well as the [City Hunter](https://anilist.co/anime/1470/) series and [Lupin III: Part III](https://anilist.co/anime/1426/).

Married to animator [Sachiko Kamimura](https://anilist.co/staff/112663/).

(Source: Wikipedia)

[Official Website](http://www.vap.co.jp/ohno/) | [Twitter](https://twitter.com/lupinjazz) | [Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/大野雄二)

Yuuji Oono is a Japanese jazz musician, composer and arranger.

He is known for his musical scoring of Japanese anime television series, particularly entries in the [Lupin III](https://anilist.co/anime/1412/) franchise. Most famously the 1977 series [Lupin III Part II](https://anilist.co/anime/1425/) and the noted [Miyazaki](https://anilist.co/staff/96870/) feature film titled [The Castle of Cagliostro](https://anilist.co/anime/1430/). Later anime series scored by Oono include [Shingu: Secret of the Stellar Wars](https://anilist.co/anime/1179/), the 1978 Toei series [Captain Future](https://anilist.co/anime/2561/) and the 1982 series [Space Adventure Cobra](https://anilist.co/anime/2451/). He has composed scores for live-action films, namely Toei's tokusatsu series Seiun Kamen Machineman, his only work on this genre to date.

Oono is also a member of a jazz trio with Czech bassist Miroslav Vitous and American drummer Lenny White, The Lupintic Five (later The Lupintic Six) and You & The Explosion Band.

(Source: Wikipedia)

Araki developed an interest for drawing at age five. He graduated in Aichi Prefecture. In 1955, at age eighteen, he debuted as a cartoonist in the "Machi" magazine. He then joined Mushi Production as animator in 1964 and later founded Studio Jaccard in 1966. In 1970, he debuted as animation director on [Ashita no Joe](https://anilist.co/anime/2402/), and later worked on the anime adaptations of several of [Gou Nagai](https://anilist.co/staff/97992/)'s manga, including [Devilman](https://anilist.co/anime/2252/), [Cutie Honey](https://anilist.co/anime/1661/), and [UFO Robo Grendizer](https://anilist.co/anime/1985/), serving as a character designer on the latter two. In 1971 he founded Studio Z together with his friends in the business.

He frequently worked with animator [Michi Himeno](https://anilist.co/staff/113357/), who he met in 1973. Araki formed Araki Production in 1974 and Himeno was the first member of the studio.

Araki was also an animator on several American productions which outsourced animation work to Japan, including Mighty Orbots (1984, key animation), The Adventures of the American Rabbit (1986) and G.I. Joe: The Movie (1987).

He passed away due to heart failure on December 1, 2011.

He passed away due to heart failure on December 1, 2011.

__Birthplace:__ Ibaraki Prefecture, Japan

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/%E5%A4%A7%E5%B7%9D%E4%BF%8A%E9%81%93)

Toshimichi Ookawa is a screenwriter and film director.

He graduated from the Faculty of Law, Meiji University in 1980. Made his screenwriting debut on Taiyou ni Hoero, a long-running prime-time detective series. In anime he debuted as a screenwriter on [Cat's Eye](https://anilist.co/anime/2043/).

He is an animator and character designer. Motohashi started working at Studio Z. Later, after leaving Studio Z, he started together with Hirayama Satoshi and Kamegaki Hajime Studio Z5. Today he is affiliated with Xebec and is the representative director of its subsidiary Xebec M2.

Sonia Rosa is a Brazilian singer of bossa nova and Japanese music. She recorded her first album in 1968, selling over 2 million copies, establishing the first Brazilian that produced the most albums in Japan, totaling 32, culminating in a consolidated career in Asian lands and soon after moved to Japan. a year later, she recorded her second album in the studio in Tokyo, the EMI. Sonia had the cooperation of renowned Japanese jazz musicians such as saxophonist Sadao Watanabe and the his quartet, Shunichi Makaino, Kunihiko Suzuki, Koichi Uzaki and Akio Miyazawa. His repertoire undoubtedly is dug in Bossa Nova and perhaps the softness of Sonia voice and some rhythmic similarities, melodic and harmonic.

(Source: MAL, edited)

Japanese filmmaker, actor, and screenwriter. His films are renowned by film enthusiasts worldwide for their jarring visual style, irreverent humour, nihilistic cool and entertainment-over-logic sensibility. He made 40 predominately B-movies for the Nikkatsu Company between 1956 and 1967, working most prolifically in the yakuza genre. His increasingly surreal style began to draw the ire of the studio in 1963 and culminated in his ultimate dismissal for what is now regarded his magnum opus, Branded to Kill (1967), starring notable collaborator Joe Shishido. Suzuki successfully sued the studio for wrongful dismissal, but he was blacklisted for 10 years after that. As an independent filmmaker, he won critical acclaim and a Japanese Academy Award for his Taishou Trilogy, Zigeunerweisen (1980), Kagero-za (1981) and Yumeji (1991).

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/桜井正明)

_Note: Not to be confused with the [animator](https://anilist.co/staff/118601/)._

[Official Website](http://www.vap.co.jp/ohno/) | [Twitter](https://twitter.com/lupinjazz) | [Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/大野雄二)
